title: 114_hr4764
content: The Act may be cited as the "Puppies Assisting Wounded Servicemembers (PAWS) Act of 2016". The findings of Congress highlight the prevalence of post-traumatic stress disorder among returning Armed Forces members from Operation Iraqi Freedom or Operation Enduring Freedom. Dogs can help mitigate this stress response, improving symptoms such as anxiety, fear, social isolation, and sleep disturbances. The pilot program aims to provide service dogs to veterans with severe post-traumatic stress disorder. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will implement a pilot program to provide service dogs to eligible veterans with severe post-traumatic stress disorder. Veterans must be diagnosed with a severity level of three or four on the Clinician-Administered PTSD Scale for DSM-5 to be eligible for a service dog under the program. The pilot program provides service dogs to eligible veterans with severe PTSD who have not improved with established therapies. Veterans must have served after September 11, 2001, completed evidence-based treatment, and show significant symptoms. To remain eligible, veterans must regularly see a primary care or mental health provider at the VA. The pilot program provides service dogs to eligible veterans with severe PTSD who have not improved with established therapies. Veterans must regularly see a primary care or mental health provider at a VA facility. The Secretary will enter into contracts for the procurement and training of service dogs with certified providers, ensuring at least 30 hours of one-on-one training over 90 days. The pilot program provides service dogs to eligible veterans with severe PTSD. Veterans must receive at least 30 hours of training with their new service canine, pass the Canine Good Citizen test, and receive follow-up support. The Secretary is limited to spending $27,000 on each dog. After the program ends, a report will be submitted to Congress evaluating its effectiveness. The pilot program evaluates its effectiveness in helping veterans with severe PTSD live normally, reducing symptoms, and decreasing reliance on prescription medications. The Comptroller General will provide recommendations on continuing or expanding the program. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of $10,000,000 for fiscal years 2017-2022 to fund the pilot program. Appropriations for Department of Veterans Affairs Office of Human Resources and Administration will be reduced by $10,000,000. The pilot program will terminate five years after the enactment of the Act.
